content.question:
<math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2 solid is in equilibrium with C a with a positive 2 charge aqueous plus 2 O H with a negative one charge aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>⇄</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>Ca</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="K sub s p is equal to 5.5 times 10 to the negative 6 power at 298 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>5.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></msup><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>at</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
The equilibrium in a saturated solution of <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented above. In an experiment, a student places <math alttext="5.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of distilled water and stirs the mixture. How would the results be affected if the student repeats the experiment but this time places <math alttext="5.0 grams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="C a, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2 solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>Ca(OH)</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>s</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> into <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.0010 molar N a O H aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.0010</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> instead of distilled water?

choices.label: Less solid will dissolve, because the larger value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will cause the equilibrium position to lie farther to the right.

Less solid will dissolve, because the larger value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will cause the equilibrium position to lie farther to the left.

More solid will dissolve, because the larger value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will cause the equilibrium position to lie farther to the right.

More solid will dissolve, because the smaller value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will cause the equilibrium position to lie farther to the left.

content.answer: Less solid will dissolve, because the larger value of <math alttext="the molar concentration of O H with a negative one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>[OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>]</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> will cause the equilibrium position to lie farther to the left.

skill.text: 2.F: Explain how modifications to an experimental procedure will alter results.
